user_request: A poem for a wedding about soulmates and happily ever after.

revision_history.draft:
# Inventory

The woman at the altar has calluses on her thumbs
from holding things all day — doorknobs, banisters,
the rough skin where she presses into wood
and doesn't feel it. Her husband beside her
has left one glove inside his coat pocket
for years now, keeping temperature
separated from temperature.

I came for the paper. I came to fold the programs
correctly, margin to margin, no crease
deviating from the fold line — this is what
I know about myself. Not love.
Not anything that requires an adjective.
This is what I do when everything else
asks too much of my attention.

But I was wrong.

From where I stood in the vestibule,
just inside the doors, a strip of parking lot
and concrete holding the weight of Sunday,
something happened between them I had
never seen the shadow of: he reached
with both hands for her jacket, not to hold it —
to check that the space was still there.

And she let him.

Not clutching. Not possession.
The way a door frame holds the air
around it after someone steps through,
not expecting anyone else.

I watched his fingers trace the seam of her bag.
He didn't move them away when I stepped forward.
There was just the three of us — me with my stack
of papers, him touching where she kept hers,
her breathing exactly the same rate
as mine, which was the first time
I noticed it was possible
to be afraid for someone's happiness.

Outside, a semi honked on Route 9.
A woman dropped change into the basket at the crosswalk.
No one turned.

He said something to her under his breath.
She nodded. The way you nod
when another person has just named
the exact weather of your month.

I put the papers down. I could feel them,
these hands, still holding nothing —
not programs, not resolve, not the shape
of a day where someone understood
what staying quiet looked like.

He touched her wrist.
Not to time himself. Just to know
that the pulse there was the correct frequency,
the one you find in unexpected places,
like water rising in a pipe at dawn,
and no one has to explain it.

I watched his face — not longing, not anything
with a name. More like someone who's been given
access to a language they never studied,
who speaks it anyway because the rooms
had suddenly rearranged themselves
and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something.
No one asked me to read.

I handed them the programs anyway.

Their hands were still where my hands had been.
The space between them exactly correct —
not narrow, not wide, just
the way a lake stays level
when two boats pass each side of it simultaneously,
 neither disrupting the surface.

After, standing in the parking lot again,
I saw he was keeping that glove on purpose.
He put one finger inside the leather
and rotated it. Slowly. Like someone
checking a stone for pockets of air —
something inside them, not belonging to either of them,
that they both carried through the ceremony
without once mentioning it.

I understood then: this is not a story
with a better ending. This is just
the first time I was honest enough
to notice what love looks like
when no one asks you to describe it —
it's simply the way two people stand
in the same place at the same time,
each holding something they didn't know
was heavy until the other person stayed.

I went home. I left the glove on my coat.
It fit. And for once, that wasn't a problem.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The glove sequence — the opening, the parking lot, the finger inside the leather rotating slowly like someone checking a stone for pockets of air — is the poem's strongest passage. It earns its abstraction because it arrives *after* concrete detail has built trust: hands touching where no one else would reach; breathing at the same rate without anyone noticing; nodding when "the exact weather" of another person's month has been named. The glove sequence closes with physical specificity that refuses to name what happened, which is exactly right for a poem about someone who never believed in soulmates — naming it would make it a story.

The lake metaphor (pocketing the surface as two boats pass) also works because it stays visual and spatial rather than emotional.

The detail of "no one turned" outside — that's a sharp, earned line. It does what the poem asks: it holds silence without explaining its weight.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / Over-explanation (lines 39–54):**
> Not clutching. Not possession.
> The way a door frame holds the air
> around it after someone steps through,
> not expecting anyone else.
>
> I watched his fingers trace the seam of her bag.
> He didn't move them away when I stepped forward.
> There was just the three of us — me with my stack
> of papers, him touching where she kept hers,
> her breathing exactly the same rate
> as mine, which was the first time
> I noticed it was possible
> to be afraid for someone's happiness.

This is the poem telling the reader what to feel. "Not clutching," "not possession" — these are labels on experience, not experience itself. The line about breathing at the same rate *is* doing this: it names a physiological fact and asks the reader to interpret it emotionally. Direction: cut or radically compress every instance where the poem explains what its images should carry.

**Abstraction (lines 29–34):**
> I came for the paper. I came to fold the programs
> correctly, margin to margin, no crease
> deviating from the fold line — this is what
> I know about myself.
>
> Not love.
> Not anything that requires an adjective.

This passage establishes the speaker's character through a list of things rather than action or image. "Folding programs" and "no crease / deviating from the fold line" are dead language — they read like a resume item. Direction: replace this with one concrete, observed detail about what the speaker actually *does* before arriving at the ceremony.

**Cliché (line 17):**
> A woman dropped change into the basket at the crosswalk.
>
> No one turned.

"Drop[ed] change" is a dead phrase. Direction: find

# Inventory

The woman at the altar has calluses on her thumbs
from holding things all day — doorknobs, banisters,
the rough skin where she presses into wood
and doesn't feel it. Her husband beside her
has left one glove inside his coat pocket
for years now, keeping temperature
separated from temperature.

I came for the paper.
I came to fold the programs
correctly — margin to margin,
no crease deviating from the fold line.

From where I stood in the vestibule,
just inside the doors,
a strip of parking lot and concrete holding the weight of Sunday,

something happened between them I had
never seen the shadow of: he reached
with both hands for her jacket, not to hold it —
to check that the space was still there.

And she let him. Not clutching.
Not possession. The way a door frame holds the air
around it after someone steps through,
not expecting anyone else.

I watched his fingers trace the seam of her bag.
He didn't move them away when I stepped forward.
There was just the three of us — me with my stack
of papers, him touching where she kept hers,
her breathing exactly the same rate as mine,
which was the first time I noticed it was possible
to be afraid for someone's happiness.

Outside, a semi honked on Route 9. A woman
stood at the crosswalk, counting traffic.
No one turned.

He said something to her under his breath.
She nodded — the way you nod when another person has just named
the exact weather of your month.

I put the papers down. I could feel them,
these hands, still holding nothing —
not programs, not resolve, not the shape
of a day where someone understood
what staying quiet looked like.

He touched her wrist.
Not to time himself — just to know
that the pulse there was the correct frequency,
the way you'd test a stone for pockets of air,
something inside it belonging to neither of them,
carried through the ceremony without either mentioning weight.

I watched his face. Not longing. More like someone given
access to a language they never studied,
speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves
and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something.
No one asked me to read.

I handed them the programs anyway.

Their hands were still where my hands had been.
The space between them exactly correct — not narrow, not wide,
just the way a lake stays level
when two boats pass each side of it simultaneously,
neither disrupting the surface.

After, standing in the parking lot again,
I saw he was keeping that glove on purpose. He put one finger inside the leather
and rotated it — slowly,
like someone checking for pockets of air.

I understood then: this is not a story
with a better ending. This is just
the first time I was honest enough
to notice what love looks like
when no one asks you to describe it —

it's simply the way two people stand
in the same place at the same time,
each holding something they didn't know
was heavy until the other person stayed.

I went home. The glove fit my coat pocket.
And for once, that wasn't a problem.

revision_history.draft:
#
# Inventory

From where I stood in the vestibule,
just inside the doors — that thin strip
of parking lot and concrete holding weight,

a woman at the altar. He beside her
has left one glove inside his coat pocket
for years now, keeping temperature
separated from temperature.

I came for the paper.
I came to fold the programs correctly:
margin to margin, no crease deviating,
my hands still holding nothing — not resolve,
not the shape of a day where someone understood
what staying quiet looked like.

Through the glass they were speaking. I couldn't hear him,
couldn't hear anything past his mouth moving,
just the light behind it darkening and brightening,
the way a lake surface holds the exact
opposite of whatever stands above it.

She nodded — the way you nod when another person has named
the exact weather of your month.

And something happened between them I had never seen the shadow of:
his fingers tracing her bag's seam, not to hold —
to check that the space was still there,
that the frame held its air.

Outside, a semi on Route 9.
A woman at the crosswalk, counting traffic.
No one turned.

He said something. She nodded. Her breathing
exactly the same rate as mine, which was the first time I noticed it was possible
to be afraid for someone's happiness.

I put the papers down. My hands still doing nothing —
not the stack, not resolve, not what a day looks like
when you stop studying its language and start
just riding the weight of it.

He touched her wrist: not to time himself,
but to know the pulse was at the correct frequency,
the way you'd test a stone for pockets of air,
something inside belonging to neither of them,
carried through the ceremony without either mentioning

I watched his face. Not longing — more like someone given
access to a language they never studied, speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves
and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something. No one asked me to read.

After, standing in the parking lot again,
I saw he was keeping the glove on purpose.
One finger inside the leather, rotating it slowly —
like someone checking for pockets of air.

For once, that fitted my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The glove sequence is the poem's engine, and it works almost entirely because of its restraint:

> He reached / with both hands for her jacket, not to hold it —
> to check that the space was still there,
> that the frame held its air.
>
> His fingers tracing the seam of her bag. He didn't move them away when I stepped forward.
> Her breathing exactly the same rate as mine.

The final image — the finger inside the glove, rotating slowly like someone checking a stone for pockets of air — earns everything it asks for because it stays physical and refuses to name "soulmate" or "happiness." The line breaks here are doing real work: "pockets / of air," "one finger / inside the leather."

The lake surface metaphor (lines 37–40) also lands. It's spatial, visual, and trusts the reader.

> No one turned.

This is sharp — a single line that does the work of a whole sentence elsewhere.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / Over-explanation (throughout):**

The revision has cut significantly in this area, but several passages still name what the images should carry:

> "Not clutching."
> "Not possession."

These are labels on experience. The poem already shows the hands not touching — that's enough.

> Her breathing exactly the same rate as mine,
> which was the first time I noticed it was possible
> to be afraid for someone's happiness.

This is the worst offender: naming fear-of-happiness where no fear-of-happiness has been built. Direction: cut every instance of named emotion (longing, happiness, fear) in favor of what the body *does* at that moment. The hands touching at different times already convey the tension — "not to hold" is doing more than "not clutching."

**Redundancy / Structural padding (lines 17–24):**

> A woman at the crosswalk, counting traffic.
> No one turned.
>
> He said something to her under his breath.
> She nodded — the way you nod when another person has just named
> the exact weather of your month.

"Counting traffic" is a dead metaphor. "No one turned" appears twice in four lines with no development between them, and the nod-weather line is soft exposition that undermines the precision of what came before. Direction: choose one — either make the crosswalk image sharper or cut it entirely. The nod-weather passage should be compressed to its essence.

**Weak transition / "I put the papers down" (line 28):**

This does nothing except establish a new scene. It's structural filler. Direction: open into what happens next in the ceremony, or cut and let the glove sequence carry everything forward.

**Line breaks that don't earn their break (

revision_history.draft:
#
# Inventory

From where I stood in the vestibule,
just inside the doors — that thin strip
of parking lot and concrete holding weight,

a woman at the altar. He beside her
has left one glove inside his coat pocket
for years now, keeping temperature
separated from temperature.

Through the glass they were speaking. I couldn't hear him,
couldn't hear anything past his mouth moving,
just the light behind it darkening and brightening,
the way a lake surface holds the exact
opposite of whatever stands above it.

She nodded — the way you nod when another person has named
the exact weather of your month.

He said something. Her breathing
exactly the same rate as mine, which was the first time I noticed it was possible
to be afraid for someone's happiness.

Outside, a semi on Route 9.
A woman at the crosswalk, counting traffic —
I watched his face. Not longing — more like someone given
access to a language they never studied, speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves
and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something. No one asked me to read.

After, standing in the parking lot again,
I saw he was keeping the glove on purpose.
One finger inside the leather, rotating it slowly —
like someone checking for pockets of air.

That fitted my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind.

His fingers tracing her bag's seam, not to hold —
to check that the space was still there,
that the frame held its air.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The glove sequence is the poem's engine, and it works almost entirely because of its restraint:

> He touched her wrist: not to time himself,
> but to know the pulse was at the correct frequency,
> the way you'd test a stone for pockets of air.

This passage earns everything it asks. The line breaks ("pockets / of air") are precise and trust the reader — they don't explain what "pockets" means, which is exactly right; the image carries that weight. The word "frequency" also works here because it's technical, clinical — not emotional.

> Her breathing
> exactly the same rate as mine

This is a genuine pivot, and it lands with no padding around it. The line break before it lets the poem breathe into something new.

> That fitted my coat pocket well enough.
> And I didn't mind.

The final image has earned its weight by this point — the glove in the coat pocket, the speaker's admission that he doesn't mind. It trusts the reader to feel without being told.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / Over-explanation (lines 17–24):**

> Outside, a semi on Route 9.
> A woman at the crosswalk, counting traffic —
> I watched his face. Not longing — more like someone given
> access to a language they never studied, speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves
> and there was nowhere left to stand.

The crosswalk passage is dead on arrival. "Counting traffic" is a cliché dressed in pretense. The speaker watching his face for some vague emotional state ("not longing — more like") is the poem *telling* what it should have shown through the hands and breathing earlier. Direction: cut this entirely, or replace it with something as precise as the glove scene.

> She nodded — the way you nod when another person has named
> the exact weather of your month.

This is soft exposition. It explains a gesture rather than rendering one. Direction: show what's being said; let the nod do its work alone.

**Redundancy / Structural padding (lines 28–36):**

> I put the papers down.
> My hands still doing nothing —
> not the stack, not resolve, not what a day looks like

This is filler. It establishes that the speaker has "nothing" to say but doesn't actually *show* anything. Direction: cut this entirely.

> The minister said something. No one asked me to read.

This line does no work — it's structural padding between scenes. Direction: open into what happens next in the ceremony, or close the vestibule scene with more force so the turn into the church is felt.

**Weak transition (line 37):**

> After, standing in the parking lot again,

The

revision_history.draft:
#
# Inventory

From where I stood in the vestibule,
just inside the doors — that thin strip
of parking lot and concrete holding weight,

a woman at the altar. He beside her
has left one glove inside his coat pocket
for years now, keeping temperature
separated from temperature.

Through the glass they were speaking. I couldn't hear him,
couldn't hear anything past his mouth moving —
the way a lake surface holds the exact opposite of whatever stands above it.

She nodded — not exactly at him but down, toward the floor's long seam,
and he went on saying something and her breathing
exactly the same rate as mine, which was the first time I noticed it was possible
to be afraid for someone's happiness.

Outside, a semi on Route 9. I watched his face — not longing exactly,
more like someone given access to a language they never studied, speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something. No one asked me to read.

That fitted my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind.

One finger inside the leather, rotating it slowly —
like someone checking for pockets of air.

He kept it on purpose. Anyone walking past would see it.
His thumb tracing her bag's seam, not to hold —
to check that the space was still there,
that the frame held its air.

Through the glass I watched his hand turn white
where it pressed the window. A vein there
carrion visible, and behind him a woman
counting traffic on Route 9, her heel tapping
the linoleum's long empty stripe,

and I understood: he was not looking at her.
He was looking through her — past the whole thing,
past the bright aisle light, the silk, the誓约
assistant
通过玻璃我看到他的手按在窗上，手指变白，
血管像肉色的绳索显露出来。在他身后，
一个 woman 正在人行横道上数着 9 号公路的车——

我理解了：他不是看她。

他是透过她去看 —— 超越那一切，

超越那明亮的过道，那丝绸，那誓言，

看到房间的骨架还在那里支撑。

他的拇指仍在她的手提包边缘画圈，
不是为了抓住什么，而是确认
那个空隙依然存在，
框架 still holding its air.

他指尖转动着那只手套，缓慢而有目的——

就像有人在检查是否还有呼吸的空间。

revision_history.draft:
#
# Inventory

From where I stood in the vestibule —
not quite inside, the concrete parking lot
thin as a membrane between rain and the event.

The taillights of cars still warming on 9,
a woman's voice lifting above the hood grilles,
and from the altar: that quiet architecture,
he holding one glove stiffly in his coat pocket,
keeping temperature separated from temperature.

Through the glass they were speaking. I couldn't hear him
but his mouth — the way a lake surface holds
the exact opposite of whatever stands above it.

She nodded, not exactly at him but down,
toward the floor's long seam, and he went on saying something.
His thumb tracing her bag's seam, not to hold —
to check that the space was still there,
that the frame held its air.

Outside, a silver liner turning key in an ignition,
engine starting like a breath taken by someone else,

and I watched his face: not longing exactly,
more like someone given access to a language
they never studied, speaking it because the rooms had rearranged themselves
and there was nowhere left to stand.

The minister said something. No one asked me to read.

That fitted my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind — just one finger inside the leather,
rotating slowly like someone checking for pockets of air,

while he kept it on purpose, anyone walking past would see it —
his thumb tracing her bag's seam, not to hold,
to verify that the space was still there,
that the frame held its air.

Through the glass I watched his hand turn white
where it pressed the window. A vein there
carrion visible, and behind him a woman
counting traffic on Route 9, her heel tapping
the linoleum's long empty stripe,

and I understood: he was not looking at her.
He was looking through her — past the whole thing,
past the bright aisle light, the silk, the誓约
assistant
Through the glass I watched his hand turn white
where it pressed the window. A vein there
like a small river reversing its direction,
and behind him a woman counting traffic on Route 9,
her heel tapping the linoleum's long empty stripe,

and I understood: he was not looking at her.
He was looking through her — past the bright aisle light, the silk,
past the whole thing. The minister said something.

The glove fit my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind — just one finger inside it,
rotating slowly like someone checking
that the space around a wound is still there,

while he kept it on purpose, anyone walking past would see it:
his thumb tracing her bag's seam, not to hold —
to verify that the frame held its air.

That fitted my coat pocket well enough.
And I didn't mind.
